title: Classic Yeasted Coffee Cake
full_text:
Classic Yeasted Coffee Cake
Close
Jump to recipe
Prep
45 mins
Cook
35 mins
Proofing, Resting, and Cooling Time
5 hrs 50 mins
Total
7 hrs 10 mins
Serves
8
Makes
1 9-inch coffee cake
Cook Mode
(Keep screen awake)
Ingredients
For the Tangzhong:
80
g
whole milk
(about 2 3/4 ounces; 1/3 cup)
16
g
bread flour
(1/2 ounce; 2 tablespoons)
For the Dough:
60
g
whole milk
(about 2 ounces; 1/4 cup), cold
256
g
bread flour
(9 ounces; 2 cups)
56
g
unsalted butter
(about 2 ounces; 4 tablespoons), softened
3
large
egg yolks
30
g
granulated sugar
(1 ounce; 2 tablespoons)
1 1/2
teaspoons
instant
yeast
1 1/2
teaspoons
Diamond Crystal
kosher salt
; for table salt, use half as much by volume
For the Filling:
71
g
light brown sugar
(2 1/2 ounces; 1/3 cup)
16
g
all-purpose flour
(1/2 ounce; 2 tablespoons)
1 1/2
teaspoons
ground cinnamon
1/4
teaspoon
Diamond Crystal
kosher salt
; for table salt, use half as much by volume
30
g
finely chopped pecans
(1 ounce; 1/4 cup)
14
g
unsalted butter
(about 1/2 ounce; 1 tablespoon), melted
To Finish:
Nonstick spray
100
g
pecan halves
(3 1/2 ounces; 1 cup)
14
g
unsalted butter
(about 1/2 ounce; 1 tablespoon), melted
100
g
confectioners sugar
(3 1/2 ounces; 1 cup)
1
tablespoon
(15ml)
whole milk
, plus more as needed
1/2
teaspoon
vanilla extract
Pinch
kosher salt
Directions
For the Tangzhong:
In a small saucepan, whisk milk and flour to combine. Cook over medium heat, whisking constantly, until mixture thickens to a stretchy pudding-like consistency, 2 to 3 minutes.
Serious Eats / Debbie Wee
For the Dough:
Using a flexible spatula, scrape hot tangzhong into the bowl of a stand mixer fitted with the dough hook attachment; let cool until just warm to the touch, about 10 minutes. Add cold milk to tangzhong, followed by the flour, butter, egg yolks, sugar, yeast, and salt. Mix on low speed until dough is smooth, supple, and elastic, 12 to 15 minutes. (The dough should pass the “windowpane” test: Pull off a golf-ball-sized piece of dough and, using two hands, stretch it as thin as you can without the dough ripping. If you can see through it, the dough is ready to rest. If not, continue kneading for another 2 to 4 minutes or until the dough passes this test.)
Serious Eats / Debbie Wee
Loosely cover bowl with plastic wrap or a damp towel, and let sit at warm room temperature (75 to 80ºF; 24 to 27ºC) until nearly doubled in size, 60 to 90 minutes.
Serious Eats / Debbie Wee
Meanwhile, prepare the filling:
In a small bowl, whisk brown sugar, flour, ground cinnamon, and salt to combine. Add pecans, followed by the melted butter, using your hands to toss and gently press until the mixture is sandy. Set aside.
Serious Eats / Debbie Wee
Grease a 9-inch aluminum cake pan with nonstick spray. Line the pan with two 15-inch by 3-inch strips of parchment paper, overlapping them to form an “X” in the bottom of the pan. (There should be about 3 inches of overhang on the edges.)
Serious Eats / Debbie Wee
When dough has risen, lightly flour top of dough and transfer to a lightly-floured work surface. Roll dough into a 9- by 16-inch rectangle. Scatter the filling evenly over the surface of the dough, and starting with the long end, roll the dough up as tightly as possible. Carefully pinch dough together along the seam to seal, and gently pat log to ensure even thickness; brush off any excess flour from the dough.
Serious Eats / Debbie Wee
Gently coil dough around itself to create a circular shape. Cover with a clean, damp kitchen towel and let dough rest for 5 to 10 minutes to allow gluten to relax. Roll dough into a 9-inch wide circle about 3/4-inch thick, then transfer dough to prepared pan. Loosely cover with plastic wrap or damp kitchen towel and let rise at warm room temperature until dough appears slightly puffed, about 30 minutes. Tightly wrap cake pan with plastic wrap and refrigerate at least 2 hours and up to 12.
Serious Eats / Debbie Wee
When ready to bake, remove dough from refrigerator and let rise at warm room temperature until roughly doubled in size, dough is about 1 3/4-inches tall, and bounces back slowly when gently pressed, 1 to 2 hours.
Serious Eats / Debbie Wee
To Bake:
Adjust oven rack to middle position and preheat to 350ºF (175ºC).
Firmly press pecan halves into the surface of the dough, arranging them in a circular pattern around the dough. (Dough will deflate slightly—this is fine.)
Serious Eats / Debbie Wee
Bake until light golden brown and an instant-read thermometer inserted into the center of the cake registers 190°F (88ºC), 20 to 25 minutes. Remove cake from oven and, using a pastry brush, immediately brush cake with melted butter. Lift the parchment to remove the cake from the pan and transfer it to a wire cooling rack. Let cool until slightly warm, 30 to 40 minutes.
Serious Eats / Debbie Wee
In a medium bowl, whisk confectioners sugar, milk, vanilla extract, and salt until smooth. Glaze should be thick but pourable; if glaze seems too thick, whisk in milk, 1 teaspoon at a time, until glaze is the right consistency.
Serious Eats / Debbie Wee
Using a spoon, drizzle glaze evenly over cake. Let set for 10 minutes before slicing with a serrated knife and serving.
Serious Eats / Debbie Wee
Special Equipment
Whisk, flexible spatula, stand mixer with dough hook attachment, 9-inch aluminum cake pan, parchment paper, rolling pin, pastry brush
Make-Ahead and Storage
This cake is best enjoyed the day it’s made, but leftovers can be stored in an airtight container at room temperature for up to 3 days or wrapped tightly in plastic wrap and frozen for up to 2 months. To thaw cake, let sit at room temperature overnight.
To reheat, loosely wrap cake in foil, and place in a 350ºF (175ºC) oven until warmed through, 5 to 10 minutes.
